Description: Fragment of marble sculpture with double volute decoration. The very small fragment shows pointy roll mouldings that are accompanied by so-called ‘lips’ which frame the rims of the concave volutes. The curve of the roll mouldings shows after the verification by means of a circle template a diameter of 45 to 50 cm. The fragment is made of a fine-grained and soft limestone.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Apollo (Naukratis) (Attributed by Petrie to the 'first temple of Apollo'.)
Curator's comments: Curator’s comment: Because of the obvious concave volutes curvature, this fragment is dated the earliest in the second half of the 6th century. Therefore is cannot be part of the group showing by Koenigs in the catalogue numbers 5 to 7 of the first temple of Apollo. Furthermore it is not identifiable whether it originates from a corner capital or an altar volute of the Miletian type. Published (Koenigs 2007, 348 Cat. 48)
Bibliographic references: Koenigs 2007 / Archaische griechische Bauteile (Cat. no. 48, p.348, fig. 11.)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (AA.61) (Phase 3)
